title: 106_s1761
content: The Act is titled the "Lower Rio Grande Valley Water Resources Conservation and Improvement Act of 2000" and includes definitions for various terms. The Act defines key terms such as Commissioner, Secretary, State, and program area, focusing on water conservation in specific regions of Texas under the Lower Rio Grande Water Conservation and Improvement Program. The Act mandates a program to improve water supply in cooperation with the State and water users. It involves reviewing engineering reports for water conservation projects and evaluating alternatives like lining canals and using pipelines. The Secretary must develop the program within six months of the Act's enactment. The Secretary, in consultation with the State, will develop criteria to determine project financing priorities based on water demands, conservation amounts, efficiency improvements, and meeting specified requirements. Project sponsors seeking Federal funding must meet specific requirements, including providing a report with the total project cost, analysis on water supply impact, conservation measures, water demands, and engineering plans for operational efficiency improvements. The project sponsor must demonstrate operational efficiency improvements, water, energy, or economic savings, and sign a cost-sharing agreement with the Secretary. The Secretary must also ensure the sponsor's financial capability before providing funding. The project sponsor must demonstrate operational efficiency improvements, water, energy, or economic savings, and sign a cost-sharing agreement with the Secretary. Within 1 year of project submission, the Secretary will review and determine approval based on set criteria. Project sponsors can choose to contract with the Secretary for report preparation, with costs being 50% reimbursable. $2,000,000 is authorized for the Secretary to carry out this section. SEC. 4. LOWER RIO GRANDE CONSTRUCTION AUTHORIZATION. The Secretary may fund engineering work and infrastructure construction for water conservation projects in Hidalgo County, Texas Irrigation District #1 and Cameron County, Texas Irrigation Districts #2 and #3. The Secretary authorizes funding for rehabilitation and pumping plant replacement in Harlingen Irrigation District Cameron #1 and meter installation and canal lining in Cameron #1 Irrigation District. The non-Federal share of construction costs is 50%, with $10,000,000 authorized for implementation.
